did some checking..

this is what is posted at MDL.

Microsoft does not release the 64-bit (x64) version of Visual Studio 2012, hence only 32-bit (x86) is available.

So that is like previous versions, nothing too unusual about that.

Also if people are wondering what the difference is between the MSDN release and the WZT release is see here..

http://forums.mydigitallife.info/threads/36132-Visual-Studio-2012-WZT-VS-MSDN

basicly people figured out that they built-in key is different. The key is inserted into the setup.exe so people could actualy patch their WZT iso's to match the msdn one's if they wanted.

I think it goes with out saying that these iso's are preferred over any other ones. If your gonna get VS2012 then get the MSDN versions..

does this mean you dont need to a product key anymore?
is MSDN version free?

@vinx02: No that means that the software is downloadable directly from Microsoft if you have a MSDN subscription costing you $13,299.00 dollars a year.

if you don't know this this version of Visual Studio is wrong for you, get the express version for free. This version will only make your head spin, trust me a novice developer does not need this version, it will just slow you down and make things more difficult for you.
@millennium5: Thanks for the reply. one more question. If you have a subscription in MSDN, then all the software you download there don't need a serial or product key. am i right?

you can always pick and choose what to install though for example i only ever install c++ related components.
And there are real limitations to the free version. notably the fact that it can't do a lot of resources related stuff i think.
